0.89.text:
MS. NULAND: All right, everybody. Happy Tuesday.
I have nothing at the top. Let's go to what's

6.74.text:
QUESTION: Okay. Well, I don't really have
anything at the top because I've been away,

9.69.text:
so I'm afraid I will embarrass myself with
my ignorance --

12.83.text: MS. NULAND: Can't have that, Matt.

14.63.text:
QUESTION: -- if I start - (laughter) - so
I'll defer to someone else.

18.17.text: QUESTION: Could we start with Mali, perhaps?

21.07.text:
QUESTION: I wondered if there was an issue
- under U.S. law, you cannot provide direct

28.53.text:
aid to Mali because the - it's a nonelected
government in power at the moment. Does it

35.27.text:
preclude you providing aid to French forces
going into Mali?

40.92.text: MS. NULAND: No, it does not.

42.99.text:
MS. NULAND: But let me just make some general
points on Mali today as we go forward. As

49.65.text:
we've been saying, it's absolutely critical
to stop the offensive of terrorist groups

54.79.text:
toward southern Mali, to prevent the collapse
of the government, and to accelerate the implementation

61.55.text:
of the UN Security Council resolutions on
Mali. So it's in that context that the U.S.

68.09.text:
very much welcomes the French military action
in Mali which came at the request of Mali's

73.09.text:
President as well as support being offered
by other governments. We also, as I said yesterday,

81.24.text:
support the immediate deployment of the African-led
international support mission, and we urge

87.17.text:
the Government of Mali to move forward on
a political transition process.

92.87.text:
So what are we doing in this context? First,
as I said yesterday, as Secretary Panetta

99.48.text:
made clear yesterday, we've had a number of
requests for support from the French in support

106.90.text:
of their operation. They've asked for information
sharing, they've asked for support with airlift,

115.02.text:
they've asked for support with aerial refueling.
We are already providing information and we

122.02.text:
are looking hard today at the airlift question,
helping them transport forces from France

129.43.text:
and from the area into the theater. And also
at the refueling question, I think the Pentagon

135.12.text:
will have more to say about that as we work
through those.

138.89.text:
Here in the State Department, as I said yesterday,
we are focused very much on trying to accelerate

144.91.text:
the deployment of the AFISMA forces, the ECOWAS
forces, so we have been in touch with a number

153.33.text:
of ECOWAS governments over the last couple
of days preparing for the summit that they're

159.07.text:
going to have on Saturday to make deployment
decisions. Specifically, we've offered pre-deployment

165.23.text:
training using our ACOTA trainers. We've offered
equipment, we've offered to help lift ECOWAS

173.85.text:
forces into Mali, and we've offered the kinds
of sustainment packages post-deployment that

182.13.text:
we also offered to forces that served in Somalia.
So a number of governments are looking at

188.09.text:
all of that, and as we know, we'll have an
ECOWAS summit meeting on Saturday, which we

196.04.text:
QUESTION: I'm sorry. A couple of clarifications
on that.

199.17.text:
QUESTION: So the summit meeting is not Wednesday,
then? It's Saturday?

202.32.text:
MS. NULAND: It's Saturday. We initially understood
that it was going to be earlier in the week,

205.65.text: but it's now been moved to Saturday.

207.95.text:
QUESTION: These packages, sustainment packages,
is that part of the funding mechanisms that

215.06.text:
you're still working out? Or have you worked
those out? Is that going to be paid for by

220.43.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, more broadly, the funding
mechanism for the UN mission is still being

228.46.text:
worked out, but we are assuming that the U.S.
will be asked to contribute significantly,

235.37.text:
as we did to the Somalia operation. So to
get a jump on that, we are using some of our

242.23.text:
existing funding that we already have in the
budget, and we'll be going to the Congress

246.13.text: for additional funding over the coming days.

249.12.text:
QUESTION: Do you have numbers for the existing
funding already?

251.76.text:
MS. NULAND: I don't have any numbers I can
share at the moment. We've got some $8 million

255.83.text:
in the budget currently. In terms of the additional
ask that we're going to make of Congress,

261.16.text:
let us crunch through that a little bit. Let
us begin working with them. Some of it's going

266.33.text:
to depend on what we ascertain the needs are
when the ECOWAS countries step forward, and

272.42.text:
we begin to send out the assessment teams
with regard to needs.

275.58.text:
QUESTION: Sorry, just a couple more questions.
In the pre-deployment, will that be in the

281.32.text:
home countries of these ECOWAS, or will they
go to Mali and then the ACOTA trainers will

288.00.text:
MS. NULAND: Traditionally, the way this works,
a country identifies itself as being willing

291.99.text:
to send a battalion, some aircraft, whatever
they're contributing. Our ACOTA teams then

298.76.text:
go in and work with the government in the
home country to assess the needs, whether

304.08.text:
they're training needs, whether they're equipment
needs, whether they're logistical needs, and

307.84.text:
we work together bilaterally in support of
the larger mission before they go in, and

312.68.text:
then we help lift them in, and we provide
the sustainment packages wherever they need

317.12.text:
them, either directly to country or outside
coming in.

320.14.text:
QUESTION: And it doesn't violate U.S. policy
for the U.S.-funded ECOWAS troops to fight

328.87.text:
MS. NULAND: It does not. We are precluded
under the counter-coup restrictions from funding

335.77.text:
a military that has been involved in a coup
until democracy has been restored, but we're

340.68.text:
not precluded from assisting allies and partners
in trying to restore security to that country.

349.18.text:
QUESTION: What are we to understand the ultimate
goal now is of this? Is it just to push back

351.71.text:
the offensive that began a few - last week?
Or is it actually now to jump ahead and try

359.06.text:
and get rid of the rebel groups for good from
the region?

364.27.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, the French have spoken to
the scope of their mission. I think President

368.93.text:
Hollande had some comments today with regard
to how they see the role that they're playing.

374.66.text:
Over time, obviously, the international community's
goal as spelled out in the UN Security Council

379.49.text:
resolutions is not only to help the Government
of Mali route the terrorists who have taken

386.36.text:
up control of too much of the north of the
country, but also to be able to restore security

393.25.text:
throughout the country and to restore democracy.
We've talked about the fact that there's no

398.53.text:
purely security solution to this problem.
There also has to be a democratic solution

403.66.text:
which heals the country and addresses some
of the grievances that make these populations

408.56.text:
in the north vulnerable to the siren song
of terrorists.

416.67.text:
QUESTION: The French today called on - made
a particular call to the Gulf Cooperation

420.02.text:
Council countries for help. What kind of help
could they provide?

425.52.text:
QUESTION: The French did. I know you're not
the French, but in your opinion, what could

429.71.text:
the Gulf Cooperation Council offer in terms
of - is it financial or military or what?

434.32.text:
MS. NULAND: Frankly, Said, I don't know what
they asked specifically of the GCC, but I

440.18.text:
would refer you to the French for what they
think the GCC can help them with.

443.66.text:
QUESTION: Do you think that they are calling
on, let's say, the GCC versus, let's say,

448.99.text: the Maghreb countries for political reasons?

450.62.text:
MS. NULAND: Again, I'm not going to get into
the French relationship with GCC countries,

454.99.text:
but I think all of us in the international
community need to play any role that we can

460.29.text: in rolling back the threat inside Mali.

462.73.text:
QUESTION: Sorry, this is a very elementary
question.

464.86.text: QUESTION: What is a sustainment package?

466.26.text:
MS. NULAND: A sustainment package, generally,
once forces have deployed - and I'm now getting

472.62.text:
into DOD's territory, and I don't want the
brothers -

475.79.text:
QUESTION: Well, that's why I'm confused, because
it sounds like military speak for something

477.22.text:
that could be either cash or it could be food,
could be - what is a sustainment for --

482.03.text:
MS. NULAND: Again, this is under our foreign
military assistance programs that we run here.

489.35.text:
It generally refers to replenishment of ammunition,
replenishment of spare parts, can be anything

496.79.text:
from boots to tents to ammo, et cetera, as
units that have been in the field begin to

504.22.text:
need replenishment, if you will, of anything
from beans to bullets.

508.02.text: QUESTION: But it includes lethal - it's --

511.99.text: QUESTION: -- lethal support; it's not food?

513.02.text:
MS. NULAND: It can be food if they need food,
but it can also be parts, equipment, ammunition.

520.32.text:
QUESTION: Was there discussion of the ECOWAS
approach between the Secretary and the Liberian

525.15.text: President in their talks this morning?

526.65.text:
MS. NULAND: There was. Mali was very much
a subject that was discussed, and the upcoming

533.18.text:
ECOWAS summit. The Secretary did outline the
support that we are prepared to offer to ECOWAS

539.33.text:
countries, as she did make clear that we support
the French forces and that we are looking

546.84.text:
at how best to respond to the requests that
they've made as well.

551.27.text:
QUESTION: Toria, up until now, the country
actually - Mali was actually considered pretty

556.45.text:
progressive politically. What happened? How
do - are there larger lessons to be drawn

563.83.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, I don't know what you mean
by pre-progressive, Jill.

566.95.text: QUESTION: Well, I mean, they had a government.

568.11.text: MS. NULAND: That's not a word that I --

570.69.text:
QUESTION: They seemed to be functioning as
a government. Is there - I guess what I'm

576.62.text:
asking is, in that particular area where you
have al-Qaida and you have other groups, is

581.60.text:
there a larger lesson to be drawn from how
this very quickly devolved into a very bad

588.91.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, I think the Secretary's
been clear for more than a year now about

592.96.text:
her concern about al-Qaida's efforts to make
in-roads into various countries in that part

601.49.text:
of the world, and particularly the threat
posed by al-Qaida in the Maghreb. If you got

606.93.text:
a chance to see what the Secretary of Defense
said yesterday, he also talked a little bit

611.10.text:
about the squeeze the balloon phenomenon,
if you will, that they have been increasingly

617.13.text:
squeezed in Yemen, in Somalia, even in Libya
such that they're looking for new safe havens.

624.56.text:
So in all of the travels that the Secretary
has had in West Africa, she's spoken about

630.45.text:
not only this threat but the Boko Haram threat
in Nigeria and the risk that they link up.

636.84.text:
You remember that we were in Algeria and this
was very much a subject not too long ago.

642.68.text:
So I think we've all been watching this with
concern, and particularly after the coup,

649.60.text:
when the only result of the coup was to immobilize
the government in Bamako, both politically

656.32.text:
and in security terms, so that they were increasingly
less able to combat the slow takeover of some

663.64.text:
of these towns. But obviously, the turning
point came when the rebels began moving significantly

671.06.text:
towards Kano and were on the road to some
of these southern towns that are very strategically

678.99.text:
important. So I think it was at that point
that the Government of Mali asked for French

685.11.text:
QUESTION: It has been - just to take Jill's
point, though, it has been a pretty stunning

688.42.text:
fall from grace for Mali. I mean, 10 years
ago, they were a founding member of the Community

693.32.text:
of Democracies. They - several Secretaries
of State traveled there. It was hailed as

700.19.text:
a model for other African countries coming
out of post-colonial unrest --

708.22.text:
QUESTION: -- for tribulations. So, I mean,
is there - is it the U.S. Administration - is

716.76.text:
it the Administration's position that this
happened solely as a result of the coup?

721.42.text:
MS. NULAND: No. I mean, I think, first of
all, to agree with you. It is - for all friends

727.20.text:
of Mali, it's a great tragedy to watch what's
happened to the country. This process was

733.59.text:
greatly exacerbated by the coup in Bamako,
which had all of the political and economic

741.47.text:
energy of the country focused on the crisis
of governance in the south, rather than working

748.90.text:
on what they should have been working on,
which were addressing the grievances of the

752.08.text:
north and trying to rebind the country political
and economic progress.

758.67.text:
So over the past however long it's been, ten
months, nine months, that has allowed increasing

765.29.text:
space up in the north - which is hard to secure
anyway, hard to govern cause it's so far away,

770.57.text:
the country's very large - for the terrorist
groups to make in-roads and for the Mali Government

776.07.text:
to be divided among itself, the Mali military
to be divided among itself, rather than confronting

781.72.text:
the challenges in the country. So if there's
a lesson here, it's that coups, political

788.78.text:
coups, take countries backwards and that any
effort by terrorist groups, particularly regionally-based

797.64.text:
ones, to make inroads into ungoverned spaces,
has to be confronted firmly by the government.

803.91.text:
And if that can't happen, then there has to
be international support.

808.77.text:
QUESTION: Not to get too into the weeds with
this, but --

812.91.text:
QUESTION: Well, I think it's important, because
isn't it true that the rights of the Tuaregs

818.88.text:
were not protected sufficiently so that they
were in opposition to the government? And

825.44.text:
then in effect, their movement was co-opted
or taken over by al-Qaida.

829.90.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, I think we've said this,
that this is also an issue when you have a

834.78.text:
country that is ethnically, historically,
geographically divided, and there are a number

841.71.text:
of such countries in that region. It's incumbent
on the government to represent, work with,

850.80.text:
address the views of the entire population
so that groups are not left vulnerable; they're

857.88.text:
not left out of the political and economic
process. Because when that happens, and when

862.58.text:
you have haves and have-nots in a country,
and you have ungoverned space, those groups

867.59.text:
become vulnerable, as I said, to the siren
song of terrorists who come with great bags

873.91.text:
of money promising all kinds of things that
the government hasn't provided, and ultimately

881.10.text: just bringing more violence and more misery.

883.78.text:
So yes, rather than fighting among themselves
politically and in security terms in Bamako,

890.29.text:
they should all have been focused on addressing
the grievances in the country and trying to

895.86.text:
create a stronger, more stable Mali. So it
is quite difficult and tragic, and we all

901.56.text:
have to work with them now to try to get back
to where they deserve to be.

905.76.text: QUESTION: But to Jill's point and --

908.63.text:
QUESTION: -- Matt's point as well, are there
discussions in general about what kind of

914.33.text:
assistance the United States gives militarily
to countries that have these sort of issues?

920.88.text:
For example, the leaders of the coup, many
of them were part of the Mali army, and they

925.72.text:
were trained by the U.S. and Europe. Are there
discussions about whether you can have better

937.43.text:
training for the military and for the security
sector while not also backing up or funding

945.31.text:
or requiring the government to live up to
that type of professionalism?

950.21.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, first and foremost, starting
with the fact that we are now unable to support

956.38.text:
Malian security forces directly at all because
they were involved in a coup and we haven't

961.85.text:
yet had a restoration of democracy, so it's
enshrined in American law that we can only

968.55.text:
work with militaries that support the democratic
process and not with those who undermine it.

975.77.text: QUESTION: The coup - the argument that --

978.25.text: MS. NULAND: Can you let me address your question?

979.65.text:
MS. NULAND: Yeah. So it is a fundamental tenet
of U.S. training in all of our military-to-military

988.45.text:
cooperation programs that we focus not only
on hard security but that we also focus on

996.72.text:
citizen security, that we focus on human rights,
that we focus on democratic principles. And

1004.19.text:
the sad story here is that those Malians who
were trained in the United States did have

1011.64.text: that kind of training, including Sanogo.

1013.84.text:
So obviously there is an effort underway to
look at how we can strengthen that, and it

1020.33.text:
doesn't always succeed. But I would point
to the hundreds if not thousands of serving

1028.48.text:
officers and staff members of militaries around
the world who have been strong supporters

1034.47.text:
of democratic principles, have refused to
fire on their own people, have refused to

1039.23.text:
undercut their constitutions, in no small
part because they got exposure to those fundamental

1046.63.text:
tenets of what a democratic military does
in their training in the United States, first

1051.02.text:
and foremost the Egyptian military, as you
know.

1053.79.text: QUESTION: And secondly? Second and third?

1055.02.text: MS. NULAND: Were there second and third?

1056.47.text:
QUESTION: Yeah. Well, do the Syrians follow
that? No, they don't seem to. Any country

1060.12.text:
in Latin America over the last 30 years? They
were all trained in the U.S. They were running

1063.91.text: MS. NULAND: Matt, I'm not going to go --

1065.64.text:
QUESTION: No, no, no. You said thousands and
thousands of troops and you even mentioned

1068.62.text:
Egypt. So what other countries have there
been where militaries have refused to fire

1074.46.text:
on their own people because of human rights
training that their officers received in the

1079.06.text: United States? Can you name one?

1080.11.text:
MS. NULAND: There are a number of militaries
around the world who have been offered the

1084.04.text:
opportunity to coup on their own people and
haven't done it. I'm not going to sit here

1090.29.text:
QUESTION: At least in terms of Mali, it's
my understanding that the coup - they were

1095.78.text:
upset because while they felt like they were
being professional, they weren't being backed

1101.66.text:
up by the actual government. They weren't
necessarily firing on their own people, but

1106.76.text:
they felt like they'd had this professional
training by the West and that the Mali Government

1113.34.text:
was not backing that up. So I guess my question
is more about whether the U.S. is not just

1121.52.text:
focused on the training of the military but
whether it's also focused on insisting that

1132.88.text:
the actual governments live up to that type
of training. I don't know if that - if I'm

1139.43.text:
making sense. In other words, you had an army
that expected a certain amount of professionalism

1146.67.text:
because that's part of the training that they've
been giving. They launched a coup because

1150.83.text:
they felt like the government was not living
up to that professionalism.

1154.17.text:
MS. NULAND: Again, the answer when you have
grievances with your own government is not

1159.67.text:
to overthrow it. It is to have a democratic
discussion about how to improve the situation,

1167.29.text:
how to broaden the approach that is being
undertaken, to work through your parliament,

1172.24.text:
to work with your leaders. There's never an
excuse for violence and there's never an excuse

1176.99.text:
for overthrowing a democratic government.
Work through the democratic process to address

1183.81.text:
QUESTION: When you talk about overthrowing
a democratic government, how are you viewing

1189.15.text:
the situation in Pakistan where a mass rally
in Islamabad is calling for the government

1195.26.text:
to ramp up? The Supreme Court has issued orders
for Prime Minister's arrest. Do you have a

1202.84.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, we're obviously not taking
a position with regard to the march and all

1212.27.text:
of those - the various issues, political issues
that the marchers are out in the streets for.

1221.47.text:
What we have said is, as we say around the
world, we want to see any kind of demonstration

1226.87.text:
remain peaceful and that the government protect
the right of people to a peaceful protest

1233.85.text:
and that the protestors remain peaceful in
the way they approach things.

1238.29.text:
But with regard to the larger question of
the political future of Pakistan, that's an

1245.68.text:
internal issue for Pakistanis to resolve as
long as it is resolved in a just and transparent

1252.21.text:
manner that protects the constitution, protects
the rule of law. You know what we've said

1258.28.text:
consistently that we stand strongly in favor
of a democratically elected civilian government

1264.61.text: in Pakistan, and we'll continue to do so.

1267.03.text:
QUESTION: But does the situation where the
government is almost paralyzed affect your

1272.12.text:
ability to talk to the Pakistani Government
and work on the issues that you have been

1276.96.text: working through during the last few months?

1278.02.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, we've been talking to the
Pakistani Government throughout this period.

1283.55.text:
I think you know that Foreign Minister Khar
is in New York today and Ambassador Rice will

1290.85.text:
have a chance to meet with her. So we are
continuing - our lines of communication are

1295.20.text:
QUESTION: Will the situation in Pakistan also
be a topic of discussion?

1298.86.text:
MS. NULAND: My understanding is that Foreign
Minister Khar is coming primarily because

1306.02.text:
Pakistan is going to take the chair of the
council, so I assume that the conversation

1310.96.text:
will focus primarily on UN and multilateral
issues. But I will refer you to USUN to give

1318.70.text: you a readout after the meeting.

1319.63.text:
QUESTION: Have you issued any new security
or other kind of instructions to the Embassy

1325.26.text:
staff? Who is the Ambassador in touch with
in the Pakistani Government at the moment?

1329.10.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, the Ambassador has been
very active, as you can imagine. I'm not going

1333.43.text:
to get into details of his diplomacy. The
Embassy, though, because of the march and

1339.10.text:
the large number of people in the streets,
the Embassy has been closed for public services

1343.52.text:
yesterday and today. We anticipate it will
also be open tomorrow. The usual advisories

1351.31.text:
are out for American citizens as well to avoid
--

1354.05.text:
MS. NULAND: It will be closed for public services
tomorrow as well because of the number of

1359.15.text:
people in the streets. And the usual advisories
for Americans to stay away from crowds, et

1365.79.text:
QUESTION: There are some sections of the media
in Pakistan and several political parties

1370.31.text:
who are saying that the U.S. would also welcome
any change that is caused by this rally or

1378.73.text:
any other means because it has lost confidence
in the Pakistan Government's ability to deliver.

1384.75.text: Do you have a comment on that?

1386.34.text:
MS. NULAND: That is not our view. Our view
is that internal political issues in Pakistan

1391.57.text:
need to be resolved by Pakistanis, as I said,
in a just, transparent manner that accords

1398.65.text:
with the rule of law. And as I also said,
we stand strongly in favor of a democratically

1406.23.text:
elected civilian government in Pakistan. We
always - we have for a long time and we will

1410.87.text:
QUESTION: Has anybody from the Embassy met
Dr. Tahir-ul-Qadry, who is leading this mass

1415.13.text:
MS. NULAND: I don't have anything for you
on that one way or the other. It sounds like

1418.98.text: a pretty busy guy at the moment.

1422.23.text:
QUESTION: Yeah. You said that you didn't want
to comment on the broader political issue,

1425.65.text:
and then you laid out the principals: rule
of law --

1428.55.text:
QUESTION: -- respect for the constitution,
et cetera. Do you have a view on the narrower

1432.91.text:
question of whether the Pakistani Supreme
Court's ordering the arrest of the Prime Minister

1438.09.text: may have been a politically motivated act?

1442.52.text:
MS. NULAND: We're - our only comment on any
of this today is to say that these issues

1448.77.text:
have to be resolved among Pakistanis in a
democratic and transparent manner.

1452.84.text:
QUESTION: Well, do you regard - I mean, I
think it's a serious question because there

1457.43.text:
are cases of what State Department spokespeople
themselves say they regard as politically

1463.47.text:
motivated prosecutions, right? And when the
Supreme Court orders the arrest of the serving

1470.30.text:
Prime Minister of a country, it is a natural
question to ask. Is that a question yourselves

1475.92.text:
are asking yourselves? Is this politically
motivated? Or is it not even a question that

1481.12.text:
occurs to you, it's just the march of justice
in a democratic society.

1484.99.text:
MS. NULAND: Our - my understanding is that
this was rooted in a long case that, based

1494.99.text:
on charges that were made some time ago, we
are not in a position to evaluate the merits

1500.29.text:
of the case one way or the other. If that
changes, we'll let you know.

1504.28.text:
QUESTION: You have had the last couple days
to evaluate; do you still see value in Mr.

1512.23.text:
MS. NULAND: We do still see value in his efforts.
We do continue to support what he's trying

1517.47.text:
to do. It's never been an easy mission. He,
as you know, plans to continue his consultations.

1527.05.text:
He's going to be meeting some of the opposition
leaders in the coming days and weeks, and

1531.38.text:
he'll also be having more consultations with
the regime and we'll see where we go from

1535.72.text:
QUESTION: Although, the Syrian Government
seems to have closed the door basically on

1540.52.text: his access and welcome to Syria.

1543.54.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, I think we have to see what
happens the next time he tries to go.

1547.79.text:
QUESTION: Okay. And his predecessor, Kofi
Annan, said that he did not get the proper

1553.40.text:
support from anyone, including the permanent
members on the Security Council. Do you agree

1559.36.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, we were also extremely supportive
of what Kofi Annan was trying to do. It's

1564.58.text:
obviously been a difficult mission; it's been
difficult for all of us. Nobody would say

1568.11.text: that the situation in Syria's been easy.

1569.74.text:
QUESTION: Would you say that all members of
- all permanent members of the Security Council

1573.08.text: were full supportive of Kofi Annan?

1574.70.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, we obviously had different
views, as you know, and that was evident in

1578.90.text: the three vetoes that we had.

1580.36.text:
QUESTION: And finally, if I may ask, there
are some reports that you have concluded - or

1585.89.text:
you have reports, whatever it is, intelligence
or otherwise - that suggest that Syria is

1590.11.text:
really headed towards becoming a failed state,
that in fact the elements that are there now

1595.39.text: sort of suggest that very strongly.

1598.03.text:
MS. NULAND: I think all of the efforts that
we've been undertaking over this whole period

1602.94.text:
are designed to prevent that, to try to get
the bloodshed ended before the fabric of the

1609.33.text:
society and all of the institutions are destroyed.
The Secretary has been quite eloquent in talking

1613.54.text:
about the risks here, and we will continue
to support the Syrian people in their effort

1619.36.text:
to have a better future and to get another
chance at rebuilding their society in a democratic

1625.57.text: QUESTION: Can we go a little bit south?

1627.14.text:
QUESTION: Egypt? I'm wondering if you have
any thoughts about these comments that President

1630.87.text:
Morsi made before he was President that were
strident, shall we say, and vitriolic against

1641.36.text:
Israel and Jews and even the U.S. President
Obama. One, what do you think of them, and

1651.01.text:
two, are these the words - as a leader who
says something like this, can you really,

1657.12.text:
honestly expect him to uphold the peace agreement
with people that he describes as the descendents

1663.88.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, we obviously strongly condemn
the remarks attributed to then Muslim Brotherhood

1670.72.text:
leader Morsi in 2010. The language that we've
seen is deeply offensive; we completely reject

1678.54.text:
these statements as we do any language that
espouses religious hatred.

1684.15.text:
This kind of rhetoric has been used in this
region for far too long; it's counter to the

1690.35.text:
goals of peace. And we want to see President
Morsi make absolutely clear to his own people,

1698.12.text:
to the international community, that he respects
people of all faiths, and that this type of

1702.75.text:
rhetoric is not acceptable or productive in
a democratic Egypt from its President. So

1711.46.text:
we are obviously raising our concerns with
the Egyptian Government.

1715.63.text:
What I would say is that since he has been
President, President Morsi has reaffirmed

1721.76.text:
again and again Egypt's commitment to the
peace treaty, to working with, in both word

1727.77.text:
and deed, he's been willing to work with us
and Israel on shared objectives, including

1734.12.text:
the ceasefire in Gaza. He's been committed
to our bilateral relationship, so that is

1744.27.text:
the basis on which we are continuing to work
together going forward.

1748.16.text:
QUESTION: Well, have you - so you think that
there is still some value to be worked - to

1752.87.text:
working with him? You don't think that these
comments reflect his heartfelt beliefs? You're

1761.49.text:
seeking - I assume - you say you want to see
him make clear that he respects all faiths.

1767.20.text:
Does that mean you want him to publicly repudiate
these comments, which were captured on video

1773.21.text:
as I understand. I mean, this was quite a
big speech --

1775.00.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, we'll leave it to - we'll
leave it -

1778.33.text:
QUESTION: No, no. Do you want to see him publicly
repudiate what - these comments? And even

1783.95.text:
if he does, I mean, how can the Administration
have any faith that this man is committed

1790.81.text:
to peace with people he obviously clearly
thinks so poorly of?

1795.95.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, let's start by the fact
that we will judge him by what he does. What

1802.26.text:
he has been doing is supporting that peace
treaty, continuing to work with us and with

1809.51.text:
Israel on common goals, including in Gaza.
But we'll also judge him by what he says,

1815.81.text:
and we think that these comments should be
repudiated and they should be repudiated firmly.

1820.73.text: MS. NULAND: That's what I said.

1823.40.text:
QUESTION: So you are calling on him to retract,
apologize, or repudiate --

1826.80.text:
MS. NULAND: I think I said it pretty clearly
that he needs to make clear that he respects

1831.11.text:
people of all faiths and that this type of
rhetoric is not acceptable in a democratic

1837.33.text:
QUESTION: So, in other words, let me - I just
want to make absolutely clear, you detest,

1841.74.text:
you abhor the comments that he made, but since
he's been president you haven't seen anything

1846.90.text:
from him that would suggest that he is anything
other than committed to the peace treaty with

1854.34.text:
MS. NULAND: he's reaffirmed his commitment
to it several times. He's been acting in a

1859.96.text:
QUESTION: So as odious and deplorable as these
comments are, you have not seen them manifested

1865.59.text:
at all since he's - in his actions while he's
been president?

1870.57.text:
MS. NULAND: We have not, but we still think
that he needs to make clear his views.

1874.02.text:
QUESTION: All right. Okay. Can I turn the
coin around?

1876.10.text: QUESTION: This is about Israel now.

1879.53.text:
QUESTION: As you know, Israel is refusing
- threatened to refuse to submit its Universal

1887.12.text:
Periodic Review of Human Rights to the Human
Rights Council. I'm wondering how strongly

1893.21.text:
you think that this is a bad idea. What have
you been telling the Israelis about it? And

1900.59.text:
do you think that they should participate,
even though the council - you have problems

1907.24.text:
with the council, and they have serious problems
with the council?

1910.81.text:
MS. NULAND: Matt's referring to the fact that
in the Human Rights Council, all states are

1916.18.text:
reviewed every four years. The U.S. submits
to these kinds of reviews as well. We think

1922.53.text:
it's important for all UN member-states to
appear for their own Universal Periodic Review.

1929.44.text:
Frankly, this is an opportunity for that member-state
once every four years to report on its own

1937.46.text:
views of the human rights situation inside
of its country and to receive nonbinding,

1944.06.text:
expert advice and recommendations on how to
improve those conditions. We do it; we find

1953.39.text:
That said, we've also consistently registered
our opposition to the council's consistent

1959.85.text:
anti-Israel bias. It doesn't serve the interests
of the council to single out any one country

1966.44.text:
in an unbalanced manner. But nonetheless,
we think it's in Israel's interest. Obviously,

1970.80.text:
they'll decide their own interest. But we
think that Israel, like all countries, serves

1977.69.text:
QUESTION: Okay. When you say that you have
been consistently opposed to the council's

1985.49.text:
anti-Israel stance, and yet you still think
the Israelis should do this, you mean to say

1991.33.text:
that this is not necessarily an anti-Israel
exercise?

1995.16.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, the exercise itself is something
that all UN member-states, including the United

2001.66.text:
States, are asked to submit to every four
years. The question, obviously, is when the

2008.96.text:
report is issued, whether it is balanced,
et cetera, and whether, in the context of

2016.54.text:
the information that is gained from it, the
Human Rights Council behaves towards that

2022.81.text:
QUESTION: Right, no, I understand. But you're
telling the Israelis, "Look, just appearing

2029.08.text:
or participating in the UPR isn't necessarily
an anti-Israel exercise." Is that --

2034.92.text:
MS. NULAND: We don't consider it an anti-U.S.
exercise when we do it, if that's what you're

2039.41.text:
QUESTION: Right. Okay. So it's not an anti
anything. What happens after that might be,

2045.57.text:
but the actual participation in it is not,
and that's your argument to the Israelis?

2051.32.text:
MS. NULAND: Our argument to them is that we
think any country, rather than having the

2055.64.text:
thing go by without them participating, serves
its interests by actually appearing and representing

2063.01.text:
QUESTION: Okay. And then just on the contacts
that you had with Israel about this, where

2067.02.text:
have they - how - what level have they gotten
to? And what have you warned the Israelis

2074.10.text:
that the consequences - whether they be real
consequences or just reputational - what kind

2082.60.text:
of consequences have you warned them of if
they go ahead and boycott?

2086.73.text:
MS. NULAND: I don't think there - we've spoken
about consequences, and with regard to our

2092.30.text:
view on what they ought to do, I think this
is something that we do at the embassy level.

2100.80.text:
QUESTION: You're not suggesting that the Human
Rights Council has been biased against Israel,

2103.50.text:
MS. NULAND: Yeah. We do. We are. (Laughter.)
We are, as we have consistently said. We have

2109.33.text:
always been clear that we consider that the
disproportionate and biased opposition to

2116.92.text:
Israel within the Human Rights Council further
politicizes that body and doesn't serve the

2122.73.text:
interests of the Human Rights Council. We've
said that all along. As you know, almost every

2127.12.text:
year we have to take issue with something
that comes up in the Human Rights Council

2131.41.text:
QUESTION: So why - if you feel that way, what
is the value of doing that, or asking Israel

2135.67.text:
to appear before the council and submit a
report?

2138.12.text:
MS. NULAND: I think I just went through this;
that they're going to do a report on every

2142.40.text:
country once every four years. That country
serves itself better by appearing and making

2148.58.text:
its own case than being silent and letting
this go forward without them. That's our view.

2153.19.text:
QUESTION: On the same topic, in the last - over
the weekend, the Israelis forcibly moved Palestinians

2160.23.text:
who had tried to reclaim an area taken from
them for a settlement in the E1 area in Bab

2163.60.text: al-Shams. Do you have any comment on that?

2167.90.text:
MS. NULAND: We've obviously been aware of
recent developments in E1. I will again take

2176.12.text:
this opportunity to urge all sides, both sides,
to refrain from unhelpful action, from unhelpful

2182.98.text:
rhetoric, and to think seriously about the
consequences of their actions. Every step

2188.04.text:
taken should be designed to reduce tension,
to prepare the way for getting back to the

2194.77.text:
QUESTION: Would that be the kind of nonviolent
resistance that the Palestinians ought to

2201.58.text: MS. NULAND: I'm not sure what you're --

2203.91.text:
QUESTION: Doing - taking action like that,
going to areas and pitching tents and staying

2208.02.text:
up there and do temporary housing and staying
on land without seeking - without resorting

2214.62.text:
to violence, that would be the kind of action
that the Palestinians ought to do in sort

2220.49.text:
MS. NULAND: We oppose all unilateral action,
Said, including settlement activities of any

2226.48.text:
kind. They complicate efforts to resume direct
bilateral talks. This includes in the E1 area.

2234.78.text:
QUESTION: Toria, on adoptions, I noticed that
yesterday - I'm sorry I didn't print it out

2238.56.text:
- there was an announcement that a U.S. State
Department official is going to be going,

2243.33.text:
I believe, to Kyrgyzstan, was it, on the subject
of adoptions? And I was just wondering whether

2249.32.text:
that was something that was connected to the
Russian adoption story, or whether that's

2254.48.text:
completely separate. I guess the subtext would
be: Are you worried that some type of law

2261.20.text: like that might spread in that region?

2263.86.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, first of all, our adoption
relationship with each country is unique.

2269.44.text:
It's based on bilateral agreements and the
Hague Conventions, et cetera. So I would guess

2275.51.text:
that this was a visit that was planned beforehand.
But let me check for you, Jill, if there's

2282.29.text: QUESTION: Can I just go back to the --

2283.78.text:
QUESTION: It's not a settlement question,
per se, but do you have any comment on the

2286.07.text:
situation of these Palestinian villages in
South Hebron Hills?

2292.49.text:
MS. NULAND: I don't. Let me look into that
one, Matt.

2296.25.text:
QUESTION: And they're being forcibly relocated
because they're apparently inside an Israeli

2302.73.text:
MS. NULAND: I don't have any information on
that one. If we have anything to say, I'll

2307.40.text:
QUESTION: Following Jill's question on the
adoptions --

2308.38.text:
MS. NULAND: Let's just stay with adoptions,
and we'll go to Mr. Lee. Go ahead.

2311.14.text:
QUESTION: I believe we mentioned last week
you were holding a conference call with some

2316.01.text:
of the families, and you said that you'd update
us if you could on that. Could you just tell

2319.58.text:
us where we are and whether your figures have
changed and what the latest discussions have

2326.02.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, I think I'm not going to
go through every twist and turn in this, because

2333.49.text:
we're obviously now working intensively with
the Russians to try to work through what we

2340.31.text:
can do about these cases that were already
entrain. I don't think it serves the interest

2345.18.text:
of that process or the kids to be going through
it publicly here, Jo. So as we work through

2352.05.text:
that, if we come to any kind of resolution
that we can talk about, we'll obviously get

2355.59.text:
back to you. But you understand that our intent
is to have as many of these children able

2361.05.text: to join loving families as possible.

2363.82.text:
QUESTION: Did the figures go up or come down
as a result of --

2366.33.text:
MS. NULAND: I don't have any new update on
figures. This was less information gathering

2373.12.text:
on the cases, because we do that through the
website, and this was more a general updating

2378.45.text:
of families of the action that we were trying
to take and timelines. And there we also had

2384.16.text:
some advice to families, some of whom had
had people sitting in Russia, trying to process

2389.18.text:
things as the law came into force. So it was
more about how to work with us during this

2395.10.text:
QUESTION: And can I just ask generally, the
intense discussions that you're having with

2399.33.text:
the Russians now - what kind of tone are you
getting from the Russian side? Is it generally

2403.45.text:
constructive? Do they want to try and help
these families get through this?

2406.47.text:
MS. NULAND: Again, I think it doesn't serve
the process for us to be putting you inside

2411.26.text:
the room. Let us try to work it through in
the interest of the children.

2415.82.text:
QUESTION: This gentleman has been waiting
for a long time. After - can I ask after him?

2423.25.text:
QUESTION: Please. Thank you, Victoria. I want
to go back to Greece. I asked you yesterday

2428.71.text:
a question. There are some people in Greece
that they believe that what we see in Athens

2432.56.text:
right now - is a comeback of terrorism. What
is your comment on this?

2438.58.text:
MS. NULAND: I don't have anything further
to what I said the other day, which is that

2441.90.text:
we condemn violence of any kind. If there
are economic grievances, if there are political

2447.62.text:
grievances, they ought to be addressed in
a peaceful manner. So - but I'm not going

2454.47.text:
QUESTION: Okay. And another question. How
is your cooperation with Greece on this issue,

2463.60.text:
MS. NULAND: Has been excellent for at least
a decade and a half.

2467.49.text: QUESTION: You are not tired yet?

2468.36.text:
MS. NULAND: I am never tired. One of my feet
is asleep, but other than that, we're fine.

2474.06.text: QUESTION: Let me ask you about Japan.

2476.06.text:
QUESTION: Japan's new administration plans
to increase defense budget, military budget,

2481.79.text:
and it's apparently seeking more activity
of its self-defense forces abroad. Neighboring

2489.23.text:
countries, like China and South Korea, seem
to be concerned about the move. So what's

2496.71.text:
the State Department's formal stance, position,
on Japan's move?

2501.93.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, obviously we're consulting
with the Abe government on the direction that

2506.82.text:
it wants to go on a whole variety of things.
We look forward to having new Foreign Minister

2512.03.text:
Kishida here on Friday. I think you know that
we have Assistant Secretary Campbell and a

2517.85.text:
delegation in Seoul today, and then they'll
also be - I think they're in Tokyo tomorrow.

2523.90.text:
So I don't think we're going to comment on
some of these press reports out of Japan about

2528.48.text:
what the government might do until we get
a chance to talk to the government.

2532.58.text:
What I would say though is that Japan is a
treaty ally of the United States. We work

2537.97.text:
together very intensively on the security
of Japan, the security of the whole northeast

2543.16.text:
Asian region. Similarly, the Republic of Korea
is a treaty ally of the United States. We

2549.13.text:
work intensively on security of the Korean
Peninsula, security of the region. And we

2555.16.text:
work very closely with our two treaty allies
together, Japan and Korea and the United States,

2560.87.text:
to maintain security in northeast Asia. So
it's very, very important in this period,

2565.67.text:
where we have a new government in Japan, where
we have a government elected and getting ready

2570.67.text:
to come into office in Korea, that we continue
those bilateral consultations and the trilateral

2575.85.text:
consultations on how to keep that neighborhood
safe, and we will do that.

2581.39.text:
QUESTION: Kurt Campbell is in, like you said,
is in Seoul. He's going to meet with President-elect

2586.86.text:
Park Geun-hye of South Korea later today.
So what's going to be his main message for

2594.14.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, I obviously am not going
to preempt Assistant Secretary Campbell before

2599.83.text:
he has his meetings, just to say that he's
in Asia with Assistant Secretary of Defense

2609.23.text:
Mark Lippert and National Security Council
Senior Director for Asia Dan Russel. As I

2614.40.text:
said, this trip to Japan and Korea is an opportunity
to consult with new governments. In Korea,

2622.14.text:
he's going to be consulting with the sitting
government, but he'll also have a chance to

2626.32.text:
see Madam Park's transition team, talk about
a range of issues. I'm sure we'll talk about

2634.64.text:
the security relationship, the political relationship,
and the economic relationship going forward.

2639.10.text:
But I will let you know what I have after
they come out of there.

2643.54.text:
What I - let's see what I already have. Yeah.
They had a productive meeting with the Minister

2649.43.text:
of National Defense, Mr. Kim. In that context
of that, they discussed the regional security

2655.32.text:
situation, how we can further strengthen and
modernize our alliance on the eve of its 60th

2661.84.text:
anniversary. And tomorrow, they'll continue
their meetings with the government and with

2668.67.text: Yeah. Please. Still in Asia? Yeah. Go ahead.

2672.20.text:
QUESTION: On DPRK, Senator John Kerry - if
my memories are correct, he wrote an op-ed

2679.49.text:
in LA Times in June of 2011, criticizing the
current policy toward North Korea. It's not

2686.01.text:
working, and he think the best way is to find
a different approach and the best way is direct

2691.55.text:
engagement with North Korea. Now that Kurt
Campbell is in Seoul, and the South Korean

2699.05.text:
first woman president, she mentioned that
she might want to consider a change of the

2704.15.text:
policy toward North Korea. I just wonder is
there any discussion within the Administration

2710.71.text:
to have a policy review on policy toward North
Korea. Thank you.

2715.69.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, as I said, I think this
is an opportunity with Kurt Campbell being

2720.50.text:
in Seoul today with Danny Russel and Mr. Lippert
to hear both from the government and from

2729.72.text:
the Park team what they are thinking moving
forward and to make sure that we are working

2737.57.text:
together, as we always do, on the issues involving
DPRK and on security in the region. So to

2745.40.text:
my knowledge, there's no policy review planned
here. You know where we are on all of these

2751.27.text:
things. We've been clear about that in the
context of our concerns about the DPRK's course.

2757.54.text:
QUESTION: New topic. Can you give us a readout
on the Colombian Foreign Minister meeting

2766.89.text:
MS. NULAND: Yep. Let me see if I can find
it here. Maybe I put it in the front. So I

2781.54.text:
was not in that meeting. My colleague, Mike
Hammer, went up to it, so let me see if I

2785.00.text:
can find the notes that I had. Let me just
say generally that they obviously spoke about

2792.31.text:
the broad and deep relationship that the U.S.
and Colombia have both bilaterally and on

2798.30.text:
regional issues. It was a chance for the Secretary
to get updated on the peace talks that the

2810.88.text:
Colombian Government is conducting with the
FARC.

2813.73.text:
Here we go. The Secretary obviously expressed
admiration for President Santos' efforts to

2824.64.text:
engage in peace negotiations with the FARC
and she also praised the Santos regime for

2830.99.text:
its broad engagement on social and economic
development and human rights in the country,

2836.45.text:
including working on labor rights, land restitution,
victims' reparations, and its work with the

2842.88.text:
They also had a chance to discuss the potential
for change in Venezuela, where both counties

2853.64.text:
indicated that a political transition of any
kind needs to happen in accordance with the

2859.01.text:
Venezuelan constitution, needs to be transparent,
needs to be democratic.

2863.21.text:
And the Secretary also reiterated the U.S.
support for Colombia's accession to the OECD

2870.11.text:
and commented positively on the potential
for the Alliance of the Pacific, where Colombia

2877.54.text:
QUESTION: Any readout with the meetings with
Sinirlioglu, please?

2882.62.text:
MS. NULAND: Let me see what I've got there.
I think I've got something. Yep. So Under

2893.53.text:
Secretary for Foreign Affairs Feridun Sinirlioglu
was in the Department yesterday. He had meetings

2902.71.text:
as part of our ongoing consultation with Turkey.
He met with Deputy Secretary Burns. The Secretary

2909.38.text:
had a chance to stop in and say hello to him
during that meeting, as well as Assistant

2913.74.text:
Secretary for Europe and Eurasian Affairs
Phil Gordon, Assistant Secretary for Near

2917.66.text:
East Affairs Beth Jones, and Special Envoy
for Energy Affairs Carlos Pascual. They obviously

2924.33.text:
talked about Syria, as we always do. They
talked about Iraq and the importance of international

2931.04.text:
solidarity in Iran and efforts to promote
Middle East peace. They also discussed U.S.

2939.86.text:
continuing support for Turkey's efforts to
combat terrorism and to deepen justice and

2946.15.text:
rule of law in Turkey and to bolster U.S.-Turkish
economic ties.

2950.77.text:
QUESTION: Ayalon also was in the building
yesterday and --

2954.44.text:
QUESTION: Mr. Danny Ayalon, the Deputy Foreign
Ministry - the Israeli Deputy Foreign Minister,

2958.83.text:
he was in the building yesterday too, and
he met with Mr. Burns too. Did you raise the

2963.99.text: Turkish-Israeli relations in the meeting too?

2966.17.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, whenever we meet with Turks,
the issue of Israel usually comes up. And

2971.34.text:
whenever we meet with Israelis, the issue
of Turkey usually comes up. So I don't have

2975.79.text:
anything specific on the Ayalon meeting, but
usually we are, as allies of both countries,

2984.37.text:
trying to support increased dialogue and better
relations between them.

2989.04.text: QUESTION: A quick one for you.

2992.91.text:
QUESTION: The House said Secretary Clinton
will come down on the 23rd. Does that coincide

3000.19.text: MS. NULAND: It does. It does.

3002.62.text: QUESTION: And what about the Senate?

3004.39.text:
MS. NULAND: Again, I think we're going to
let the Senate speak for itself, but - so

3009.72.text: I would refer you to them.

3010.89.text:
QUESTION: And do you have anything on Kerry's
own hearing?

3013.55.text:
MS. NULAND: Again, I'm going to send you to
the SFRC for them to make that announcement.

3019.60.text:
QUESTION: Can you provide any update or details
on Rose Gottemoeller and Tom Countryman's

3025.69.text:
arms control/nonproliferation meetings this
week in Europe, what was talked about with

3033.38.text:
MS. NULAND: I don't have - Tom is here today,
so I'm not sure - were these meetings today?

3039.26.text:
QUESTION: I think they were earlier this week
or they were listed in the schedule for this

3043.58.text:
MS. NULAND: Okay. Let me take that and see
if we can get you anything specific.

3046.40.text:
QUESTION: Just if we could go back to Egypt
for one second --

3049.56.text:
QUESTION: Should - and Morsi's comments if
you want to grab that page. It's very brief.

3056.91.text:
Should the Egyptians expect some kind of a
deterioration in relations if these comments

3062.90.text:
MS. NULAND: I think our hope is to be able
to make our views clear and to see the kind

3071.29.text:
of action that I've called for here so that
we don't have to get into all kinds of hypothetical

3075.90.text:
QUESTION: And in your conversations with the
Egyptians about these comments, whether with

3079.95.text:
him or his aides, have you told him about
what the reaction is going to be to these

3086.80.text:
comments on the Hill and the likely uproar
that they are going to cause along with calls

3097.89.text:
for reduction or elimination in funding, that
kind of thing?

3101.60.text:
MS. NULAND: Well, we have a senior Senate
delegation that's going to be in Egypt in

3106.79.text:
the next couple of days, so I'm sure that
they will have a chance to speak for themselves,

3111.52.text:
but we certainly have made the Egyptians aware
that we are continuing to seek economic support

3119.01.text:
funds for Egypt on the Hill, and they are
very well aware that these kinds of issues

3126.26.text:
QUESTION: Okay. And then lastly - and this
has been quite a whirlwind briefing, so try

3129.55.text:
and get to the two inhabited continents that
have not been covered so far - anything new

3135.17.text:
on the Keystone environmental impact statement
which was supposed to come out last year?

3140.18.text:
MS. NULAND: I don't have anything new yet.
I think you know that we were waiting for

3144.20.text:
Nebraska to take some steps so that we could
conclude our work. My understanding is Nebraska's

3149.48.text:
only recently done that, but we'll check on
the timing for you, Matt.

3152.27.text: QUESTION: And then anything new on Australia?

3153.93.text:
MS. NULAND: On Australia? (Laughter.) Our
fabulous alliance to Down Under? Not to report

3159.90.text: QUESTION: All right. Well, we got them all.

3162.21.text:
QUESTION: One small thing, I know you've talked
about Sri Lanka a couple of times.

3167.05.text:
QUESTION: This is not about the removal of
the chief justice, but rather about the President's

3173.57.text:
choice of one of his close allies to now serve
as chief justice. Do you have anything to

3179.96.text:
MS. NULAND: Not on that particular issue except
to say that we had made clear throughout this

3187.58.text:
impeachment that we were concerned about what
it said about the democratic process, that

3193.03.text:
we were concerned about the perception of
reprisals against somebody for independent

3205.78.text:
thinking and action. So those concerns remain
with regard to the quality of Sri Lankan democracy.

3213.29.text:
QUESTION: One other thing I should have mentioned.
She is quoted today as saying that she - the

3218.94.text:
former chief justice or the ousted chief justice,
she maintains that she still is the chief

3224.18.text:
justice - is quoted as saying her life is
under threat. Do you have anything to say

3230.13.text:
MS. NULAND: I have not seen those comments.
Let me also add, as I said yesterday, that

3235.69.text:
this entire issue also serves to undermine
the international reputation of Sri Lanka

3245.00.text:
as it pertains to investment decisions that
foreign companies might make, so there is

3252.91.text:
usually a cost to this kind of thing in terms
of their ability to attract foreign investment.

3257.63.text:
QUESTION: How about to U.S. assistance if
any?

3260.83.text:
MS. NULAND: I don't have anything at the current
moment on that. Let me check up on our current

3266.12.text:
assistance situation with Sri Lanka. All right?
Thank you all.
